notes:
1. Definition

Uniform Circular Motion describes the movement of an object traveling in a circular path at a constant speed. While the speed is constant, the velocity is continuously changing because the direction of motion is always changing. This change in velocity means there must be an acceleration.

2. Key Quantities

  • Angular Velocity ($\omega$): The rate of change of angular position, measured in radians per second (rad/s). For UCM, $\omega$ is constant.
  • Period ($T$): The time it takes to complete one full revolution. $T = rac{2\pi}{\omega}$.
  • Frequency ($f$): The number of revolutions per unit time, measured in Hertz (Hz). $f = rac{1}{T} = rac{\omega}{2\pi}$.

3. Velocity and Acceleration

  • Tangential Velocity ($v$): The linear speed of the object. Its magnitude is constant and given by $v = r\omega$, where $r$ is the radius of the circle. The direction is always tangent to the circle.
  • Acceleration ($a_c$): In UCM, the acceleration is purely normal, pointing towards the center of the circle. It is called centripetal acceleration. Its magnitude is constant and given by:
    • $$a_c = rac{v^2}{r} = r\omega^2$$

    Since the speed is constant, the tangential component of acceleration is zero ($a_t = 0$).

solvedExamples.question: A satellite orbits the Earth in a circular path of radius 7,000 km. It completes one orbit in 90 minutes. What is its angular velocity in rad/s?
solvedExamples.explanation: The period $T$ is 90 minutes, which is $90 	imes 60 = 5400$ seconds. Angular velocity $\omega$ is related to the period by $\omega =  rac{2\pi}{T}$. So, $\omega =  rac{2\pi 	ext{ rad}}{5400 	ext{ s}} \approx 0.00116 	ext{ rad/s}$.

solvedExamples.question: A spinning top has an angular velocity of 10 rad/s. A point on its surface is 5 cm from the axis of rotation. What is the linear speed of this point?
solvedExamples.explanation: First, convert the radius to meters: $r = 5 	ext{ cm} = 0.05 	ext{ m}$. The linear speed is given by $v = r\omega$. So, $v = (0.05 	ext{ m})(10 	ext{ rad/s}) = 0.5 	ext{ m/s}$.

solvedExamples.question: A ball is swung in a horizontal circle of radius 2 m at a constant speed of 6 m/s. What is the magnitude of its centripetal acceleration?
solvedExamples.explanation: The centripetal acceleration is given by the formula $a_c =  rac{v^2}{r}$. Plugging in the values: $a_c =  rac{(6 	ext{ m/s})^2}{2 	ext{ m}} =  rac{36}{2} = 18 	ext{ m/s²}$.
